01-01.title: Japan's First Dream
01-01.description: In Japan, the first dream of the New Year (hatsuyume) is considered particularly important. Dreaming of Mount Fuji, a hawk, or an eggplant is considered especially lucky.

01-01.title: Scotland's First-Footing
01-01.description: In Scotland, the first person to enter a home after midnight on New Year's Day is called the 'first-footer.' A dark-haired man arriving with symbolic gifts like coal, shortbread, salt, and whisky brings the best luck.

01-02.title: Switzerland's Berchtoldstag
01-02.description: In parts of Switzerland, January 2 is Berchtoldstag, a holiday where people eat nuts and play elaborate nut games, continuing Christmas celebrations with family gatherings.

01-02.title: Japan's Kakizome Tradition
01-02.description: In Japan, January 2 is when people practice kakizome - the first calligraphy of the year, writing auspicious words or poems with special ink on long scrolls.

01-03.title: Mozart's Birthday Celebration in Austria
01-03.description: In Salzburg, Austria, January 3 marks special celebrations leading up to Mozart's birthday on January 27, with concerts and events honoring the composer's legacy.

01-03.title: Russia's Christmas Tree Disposal
01-03.description: In Russia, January 3 is traditionally when Christmas trees are taken down, as Orthodox Christmas is celebrated on January 7 and trees stay up until after the holiday.

01-04.title: Myanmar Independence Day Follow-up
01-04.description: Following Myanmar's Independence Day on January 4, traditional wrestling competitions called 'Chinlone' are held across the country as part of celebrations.

01-04.title: Colombia's Day of the Elderly
01-04.description: In Colombia, January 4 is Día del Anciano (Day of the Elderly), celebrating senior citizens with family gatherings and special community events.

01-05.title: Ukraine's Christmas Eve Preparations
01-05.description: In Ukraine, January 5 is Sviaty Vechir (Holy Evening), when families prepare a 12-dish meatless Christmas Eve supper representing the 12 apostles.

01-05.title: Ireland's Little Christmas
01-05.description: January 5 is known as Little Christmas or Women's Christmas in Ireland, when traditionally women rest while men handle household chores and cooking.

01-06.title: Mexico's Three Kings Day
01-06.description: In Mexico, January 6 is Día de Reyes (Three Kings Day), when children receive gifts and families share Rosca de Reyes, a sweet bread with a hidden baby Jesus figurine.

01-06.title: Greece's Blessing of the Waters
01-06.description: In Greece, January 6 marks Theophany, when priests throw a cross into bodies of water and young men dive to retrieve it for good luck throughout the year.

01-07.title: Egypt's Coptic Christmas
01-07.description: In Egypt, January 7 is Coptic Christmas, celebrated with special bread called 'qurban,' midnight church services, and visiting family while wearing new clothes.

01-07.title: Japan's Nanakusa Gayu
01-07.description: On January 7, Japanese people eat nanakusa gayu - a rice porridge with seven spring herbs to rest the stomach after New Year feasting and ensure health.

01-08.title: North Korea's Kim Jong-un's Birthday
01-08.description: In North Korea, January 8 is celebrated as the birthday of Kim Jong-un, marked by public celebrations, floral tributes, and special performances.

01-08.title: South Africa's Ancestral Communication Day
01-08.description: In some South African traditions, January 8 is considered an auspicious day for communicating with ancestors through traditional ceremonies and offerings.

01-09.title: Panama's Martyrs' Day
01-09.description: January 9 is Martyrs' Day in Panama, commemorating 1964 protests where students tried to raise the Panamanian flag in the Canal Zone, resulting in 21 deaths.

01-09.title: Philippines' Black Nazarene Procession
01-09.description: In Manila, Philippines, January 9 features the Traslación procession of the Black Nazarene, where millions of barefoot devotees join one of the world's largest religious processions.

01-10.title: Venezuela's Day of the Virgen de la Candelaria
01-10.description: In Venezuela, January 10 begins celebrations for the Virgen de la Candelaria, featuring traditional dancing, music, and processions in various regions.

01-10.title: Bahamas' Majority Rule Day
01-10.description: January 10 is Majority Rule Day in the Bahamas, commemorating the 1967 election when black Bahamians gained political control for the first time.

01-11.title: Nepal's Prithvi Jayanti
01-11.description: January 11 is Prithvi Jayanti in Nepal, celebrating the birth of King Prithvi Narayan Shah who unified modern Nepal, marked by ceremonies and cultural programs.

01-11.title: Morocco's Independence Manifesto Day
01-11.description: January 11 commemorates the 1944 presentation of Morocco's Independence Manifesto, celebrated with speeches and remembrance of the independence struggle.

01-12.title: Tanzania's Zanzibar Revolution Day
01-12.description: January 12 marks Zanzibar Revolution Day in Tanzania, commemorating the 1964 overthrow of the Sultan of Zanzibar with parades and cultural celebrations.

01-12.title: India's National Youth Day
01-12.description: January 12 is National Youth Day in India, celebrating the birthday of Swami Vivekananda with youth conventions, seminars, and cultural activities nationwide.

01-13.title: Sweden's St. Knut's Day
01-13.description: In Sweden, January 13 is St. Knut's Day, marking the end of Christmas when Christmas trees are taken down in a ceremony called 'julgransplundring' (Christmas tree plundering).

01-13.title: Russia's Old New Year
01-13.description: January 13 is Old New Year in Russia and other Orthodox countries, celebrating the New Year according to the Julian calendar with family meals and celebrations.

01-14.title: Georgia's National Flag Day
01-14.description: January 14 is National Flag Day in Georgia, commemorating the adoption of the national flag in 2004 with flag-raising ceremonies and cultural events.

01-14.title: Ukraine's Malanka Celebration
01-14.description: In Ukraine, January 14 is Malanka, celebrating the New Year according to the Julian calendar with costumes, masks, and traditional caroling plays.

01-15.title: Nigeria's Armed Forces Remembrance Day
01-15.description: January 15 is Armed Forces Remembrance Day in Nigeria, honoring military personnel with parades, wreath-laying ceremonies, and the release of pigeons for peace.

01-15.title: Japan's Coming of Age Day
01-15.description: The second Monday of January is Coming of Age Day in Japan, when 20-year-olds attend ceremonies wearing traditional kimonos or suits to celebrate adulthood.

01-16.title: Thailand's Teacher's Day
01-16.description: January 16 is Teacher's Day in Thailand, when students honor their teachers with ceremonies, performances, and traditional wai greetings of respect.

01-16.title: Benin's Voodoo Festival
01-16.description: In Benin, January 10-16 features the annual Voodoo Festival in Ouidah, with traditional ceremonies, dances, and rituals attracting practitioners worldwide.

01-17.title: Italy's Feast of Saint Anthony Abbot
01-17.description: In Italy, January 17 honors Saint Anthony Abbot, protector of animals, with blessings of pets and livestock, and bonfires called 'focarazzi' in some regions.

01-17.title: Philippines' Feast of the Santo Niño
01-17.description: The third Sunday of January in the Philippines celebrates the Feast of the Santo Niño (Holy Child), particularly vibrant in Cebu with the Sinulog festival.

01-18.title: Tunisia's Revolution Day
01-18.description: January 18 is Revolution Day in Tunisia, commemorating the 2011 uprising with official ceremonies and public reflections on the country's democratic transition.

01-18.title: India's Kumbh Mela Start
01-18.description: Depending on planetary positions, mid-January often marks the beginning of Kumbh Mela, the world's largest religious gathering where millions bathe in sacred rivers.

01-19.title: Iceland's Þorri Month Begins
01-19.description: In Iceland, late January marks the beginning of Þorri, a traditional month featuring Þorrablót feasts with fermented shark, smoked lamb, and other traditional foods.

01-19.title: Serbia's Orthodox Christmas Eve
01-19.description: January 19 is Orthodox Christmas Eve in Serbia, celebrated with Badnjak - the ceremonial burning of an oak branch brought into the home for blessings.

01-20.title: Azerbaijan's Martyrs' Day
01-20.description: January 20 is Martyrs' Day in Azerbaijan, commemorating victims of Black January 1990 when Soviet troops entered Baku, marked by nationwide remembrance.

01-20.title: Brazil's Saint Sebastian Day
01-20.description: January 20 honors Saint Sebastian in Brazil, particularly in Rio de Janeiro where he's the city's patron saint, celebrated with masses and cultural events.

01-21.title: New Zealand's Wellington Anniversary
01-21.description: The Monday closest to January 21 celebrates Wellington Anniversary in New Zealand, with yacht races, cultural events, and the official opening of the capital's summer.

01-21.title: Poland's Grandmother's Day
01-21.description: January 21 is Grandmother's Day in Poland, when grandchildren visit their grandmothers with flowers, gifts, and homemade cards to show appreciation.

01-22.title: Ukraine's Unity Day
01-22.description: January 22 is Unity Day in Ukraine, commemorating the 1919 unification of Ukrainian lands, celebrated with human chains and patriotic events.

01-22.title: Vincent van Gogh's Birthday Celebrations
01-22.description: In the Netherlands, January 22 sees special exhibitions and events honoring Vincent van Gogh's birthday, particularly at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam.

01-23.title: Mongolia's Lunar New Year Preparations
01-23.description: In late January, Mongolians prepare for Tsagaan Sar (Lunar New Year) by thoroughly cleaning homes, preparing traditional foods, and visiting family.

01-23.title: Bangladesh's Netaji Jayanti
01-23.description: January 23 commemorates the birthday of Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose in Bangladesh and India, with cultural programs and remembrance of his freedom struggle.

01-24.title: Romania's Unification Day
01-24.description: January 24 marks the 1859 unification of Moldavia and Wallachia in Romania, celebrated with military parades, cultural events, and official ceremonies.

01-24.title: International Day of Education (UN)
01-24.description: January 24 is UNESCO's International Day of Education, celebrated worldwide with events promoting education access and quality for all.

01-25.title: Egypt's Police Day & 2011 Revolution Start
01-25.description: January 25 is both Police Day in Egypt and the anniversary of the 2011 Egyptian Revolution, marked by reflection on the country's modern history.

01-25.title: Scotland's Burns Night
01-25.description: January 25 is Burns Night in Scotland, celebrating poet Robert Burns with suppers featuring haggis, neeps and tatties, whisky, and recitations of his poems.

01-26.title: Australia's Australia Day
01-26.description: January 26 is Australia Day, marking the 1788 arrival of the First Fleet, celebrated with citizenship ceremonies, awards, and reflections on national identity.

01-26.title: India's Republic Day
01-26.description: January 26 is Republic Day in India, commemorating the 1950 adoption of the Constitution with a grand parade in Delhi featuring cultural displays from all states.

01-27.title: International Holocaust Remembrance Day
01-27.description: January 27 is UN International Holocaust Remembrance Day, marked worldwide with ceremonies commemorating victims of the Holocaust and other genocides.

01-27.title: Mozart's Birthday in Salzburg
01-27.description: January 27 celebrates Mozart's birthday in Salzburg, Austria, with special concerts, museum exhibitions, and performances of his works throughout the city.

01-28.title: Armenia's Army Day
01-28.description: January 28 is Army Day in Armenia, marked by military parades, ceremonies honoring soldiers, and public celebrations of national defense forces.

01-28.title: Cuba's José Martí's Birthday
01-28.description: January 28 commemorates the birthday of Cuban national hero José Martí, celebrated with cultural events, speeches, and educational activities nationwide.

01-29.title: Malaysia's Federal Territory Day
01-29.description: In Kuala Lumpur, Labuan, and Putrajaya, January 29-30 celebrates Federal Territory Day with parades, fireworks, and cultural performances.

01-29.title: New Zealand's Auckland Anniversary
01-29.description: The Monday closest to January 29 celebrates Auckland Anniversary in New Zealand, featuring the world's largest one-day regatta in Waitematā Harbour.

01-30.title: Saudi Arabia's Founding Day
01-30.description: January 30 marks Saudi Arabia's Founding Day, commemorating the 1727 establishment of the First Saudi State with cultural events and historical exhibitions.

01-30.title: India's Martyrs' Day
01-30.description: January 30 is Martyrs' Day in India, commemorating Mahatma Gandhi's assassination with silent tributes at his memorial Raj Ghat in Delhi.

01-31.title: Nauru's Independence Day
01-31.description: January 31 celebrates Nauru's Independence Day from Australia in 1968, marked by fishing competitions, cultural shows, and sporting events on the island nation.

01-31.title: Scotland's Hogmanay Final Celebrations
01-31.description: In parts of Scotland, January 31 features final Hogmanay (New Year) celebrations with traditional music, dancing, and the 'first-footing' custom continuing.

02-01.title: Singapore's Chinese New Year Decorations
02-01.description: February 1 usually begins major Chinese New Year celebrations in Singapore, with Chinatown fully decorated, night markets, and cultural performances.

02-01.title: Slovenia's Culture Day
02-01.description: February 1 is Culture Day in Slovenia, commemorating poet France Prešeren's death with cultural events, poetry readings, and the Prešeren Awards ceremony.

02-02.title: Mexico's Día de la Candelaria
02-02.description: February 2 is Candlemas in Mexico, when whoever found the baby Jesus in the Rosca de Reyes bread on January 6 hosts a tamale party for family and friends.

02-02.title: Serbia's Sretenje
02-02.description: February 2 is Sretenje (Statehood Day) in Serbia, celebrating the 1804 First Serbian Uprising and 1835 adoption of the first constitution with official ceremonies.

02-03.title: Vietnam's Communist Party Founding Anniversary
02-03.description: February 3 commemorates the 1930 founding of the Communist Party of Vietnam, marked by official ceremonies, cultural events, and public celebrations.

02-03.title: Mozambique's Heroes' Day
02-03.description: February 3 is Heroes' Day in Mozambique, honoring national heroes including Eduardo Mondlane, with ceremonies at monuments and cultural presentations.

02-04.title: Sri Lanka's Independence Day
02-04.description: February 4 celebrates Sri Lanka's independence from Britain in 1948, marked by a grand parade in Colombo, cultural shows, and flag-hoisting ceremonies nationwide.

02-04.title: Angola's Start of Armed Struggle
02-04.description: February 4 commemorates the beginning of Angola's armed struggle for independence in 1961, remembered with cultural events and historical reflections.

02-06.title: New Zealand's Waitangi Day
02-06.description: February 6 is Waitangi Day in New Zealand, commemorating the 1840 signing of the Treaty of Waitangi with ceremonies at the Treaty Grounds and nationwide events.

02-06.title: Sami National Day
02-06.description: February 6 is Sami National Day, celebrated by the indigenous Sami people across Norway, Sweden, Finland, and Russia with traditional dress, food, and joik singing.

02-07.title: Grenada's Independence Day
02-07.description: February 7 celebrates Grenada's independence from Britain in 1974, marked by parades, cultural shows, and the 'Carriacou Parang Festival' with traditional music.

02-07.title: Japan's Nanakusa-no-sekku
02-07.description: February 7 is one of Japan's five seasonal festivals, celebrating the seven herbs of spring, though most traditions have merged with January 7 celebrations.

02-08.title: Slovenia's Prešeren Day
02-08.description: February 8 is Prešeren Day in Slovenia, the country's cultural holiday celebrating poet France Prešeren with cultural events and the Prešeren Awards ceremony.

02-08.title: North Korea's Military Foundation Day
02-08.description: February 8 is Military Foundation Day in North Korea, marking the 1948 establishment of the Korean People's Army with military parades and displays.

02-10.title: Nigeria's Memorial Day for MKO Abiola
02-10.description: February 10 commemorates Moshood Kashimawo Olawale Abiola in Nigeria, honoring the democracy activist with ceremonies and reflections on democratic development.

02-10.title: Finland's Runeberg's Birthday
02-10.description: February 5 celebrates Finnish national poet Johan Ludvig Runeberg, when people eat Runeberg's torte - almond cakes with raspberry jam and icing.

02-11.title: Japan's National Foundation Day
02-11.description: February 11 is National Foundation Day in Japan, commemorating the mythical founding of Japan by Emperor Jimmu in 660 BC with flag displays and patriotic events.

02-11.title: Iran's Islamic Revolution Victory Day
02-11.description: February 11 marks the anniversary of Iran's 1979 Islamic Revolution, celebrated with massive rallies, speeches, and fireworks across the country.

02-12.title: Myanmar's Union Day
02-12.description: February 12 is Union Day in Myanmar, commemorating the 1947 Panglong Agreement that unified ethnic groups, marked by cultural performances and speeches.

02-12.title: Venezuela's Youth Day
02-12.description: February 12 is Youth Day in Venezuela, honoring students involved in the 1814 Battle of La Victoria, celebrated with youth parades and cultural events.

02-13.title: World Radio Day (UNESCO)
02-13.description: February 13 is UNESCO's World Radio Day, celebrated globally with special broadcasts, events highlighting radio's importance, and recognition of radio professionals.

02-13.title: Japan's Bean-Throwing Festival
02-13.description: February 13 is the day before Setsubun in Japan, when families prepare for the bean-throwing ritual to drive away evil spirits and welcome spring.

02-14.title: Bulgaria's Winegrowers' Day
02-14.description: February 14 is Winegrowers' Day in Bulgaria, celebrating Saint Trifon Zarezan, the patron saint of vineyards, with wine tasting and pruning ceremonies.

02-14.title: Liberia's Armed Forces Day
02-14.description: February 14 is Armed Forces Day in Liberia, honoring military personnel with parades, ceremonies, and celebrations of national defense forces.

02-15.title: День державності Сербії
02-15.description: 15 лютого в Сербії — День державності на згадку про початок Першого сербського повстання 1804 року проти османського панування, відзначається офіційними церемоніями.

02-15.title: День прапора Канади
02-15.description: 15 лютого відзначають день прапора Канади, прийнятого в 1965 році, з церемоніями підняття прапора та заходами на підтримку єдності та ідентичності країни.

02-16.title: Lithuania's Independence Restoration Day
02-16.description: February 16 marks Lithuania's 1918 declaration of independence, celebrated with concerts, parades, and the raising of the national flag on Gediminas Tower.

02-16.title: North Korea's Kim Jong-il's Birthday
02-16.description: February 16 is the Day of the Shining Star in North Korea, celebrating Kim Jong-il's birthday with mass dances, floral tributes, and special performances.

02-17.title: Kosovo's Independence Day
02-17.description: February 17 celebrates Kosovo's 2008 declaration of independence, marked by concerts, fireworks, and official ceremonies in Pristina and worldwide communities.

02-17.title: Libya's Revolution Day
02-17.description: February 17 commemorates the 2011 start of the Libyan Revolution, remembered with ceremonies honoring those who participated in the uprising against Gaddafi.

02-18.title: Gambia's Independence Day
02-18.description: February 18 celebrates The Gambia's independence from Britain in 1965, marked by parades, cultural shows, and official ceremonies in Banjul.

02-18.title: Nepal's Democracy Day
02-18.description: February 18 is Democracy Day in Nepal, commemorating the 1951 end of the Rana dynasty, marked by political speeches and reflections on democratic development.

02-19.title: Mexico's Army Day
02-19.description: February 19 is Army Day in Mexico, honoring the Mexican Army with military parades, displays, and ceremonies nationwide.

02-19.title: Brunei's National Day
02-19.description: February 23 celebrates Brunei's National Day, but preparations begin around February 19 with rehearsals for the massive parade in Bandar Seri Begawan.

02-20.title: World Day of Social Justice (UN)
02-20.description: February 20 is the UN's World Day of Social Justice, observed globally with events promoting poverty eradication, gender equality, and social welfare.

02-20.title: Austria's Fasching Carnival Climax
02-20.description: Around February 20 marks the climax of Austria's Fasching carnival season, with elaborate balls, parades, and costume parties before Lent begins.

02-21.title: Bangladesh's Language Martyrs' Day
02-21.description: February 21 is International Mother Language Day, originating from Bangladesh's 1952 Language Movement, marked by tributes at the Shaheed Minar monument.

02-21.title: Zambia's Youth Day
02-21.description: February 21 is Youth Day in Zambia, focusing on youth empowerment with sports events, educational programs, and cultural performances nationwide.

02-22.title: Saint Lucia's Independence Day
02-22.description: February 22 celebrates Saint Lucia's independence from Britain in 1979, marked by parades, cultural shows, and the National Arts Festival.

02-22.title: Mexico's Flag Day
02-22.description: February 24 is Mexico's Flag Day, but celebrations begin around February 22 with educational programs about the flag's history and symbolism.

02-23.title: Brunei's National Day
02-23.description: February 23 celebrates Brunei's National Day, featuring one of Southeast Asia's largest parades with over 40,000 participants in Bandar Seri Begawan.

02-23.title: Guyana's Republic Day
02-23.description: February 23 is Republic Day in Guyana, commemorating the 1970 declaration of the Cooperative Republic, marked by cultural shows and official events.

02-24.title: Estonia's Independence Day
02-24.description: February 24 celebrates Estonia's 1918 declaration of independence, marked by flag-raising ceremonies, concerts, and the president's reception.

02-24.title: Mexico's Flag Day
02-24.description: February 24 is Flag Day in Mexico, honoring the national flag with ceremonies, educational programs, and the national pledge to the flag in schools.

02-25.title: Kuwait's National Day
02-25.description: February 25 is Kuwait's National Day, celebrating the country's independence, marked by fireworks, parades, and traditional performances.

02-25.title: Philippines' People Power Revolution Anniversary
02-25.description: February 25 commemorates the 1986 People Power Revolution in the Philippines, remembered with ceremonies at EDSA and reflections on democracy.

02-26.title: Kuwait's Liberation Day
02-26.description: February 26 is Kuwait's Liberation Day, celebrating the 1991 liberation from Iraqi occupation, marked by fireworks, concerts, and patriotic events.

02-26.title: Dominican Republic's Independence Day
02-26.description: February 27 is Independence Day in the Dominican Republic, but celebrations begin on February 26 with cultural events and preparations.

02-27.title: Dominican Republic's Independence Day
02-27.description: February 27 celebrates the Dominican Republic's 1844 independence from Haiti, marked by parades, music, and the reading of the independence manifesto.

02-27.title: Polar Bear Day
02-27.description: February 27 is International Polar Bear Day, observed worldwide with educational events about polar bear conservation and climate change awareness.

02-28.title: Taiwan's Peace Memorial Day
02-28.description: February 28 is Peace Memorial Day in Taiwan, commemorating victims of the 1947 February 28 Incident with ceremonies and reflections on democracy.

02-28.title: Finland's Kalevala Day
02-28.description: February 28 is Kalevala Day in Finland, celebrating Finnish culture and the national epic with poetry readings, cultural events, and flag displays.

03-01.title: South Korea's Samiljeol (Independence Movement Day)
03-01.description: March 1 commemorates Korea's 1919 independence movement against Japanese rule, marked by reading declarations and waving Korean flags nationwide.

03-01.title: Wales' St. David's Day
03-01.description: March 1 is St. David's Day in Wales, celebrating the patron saint with people wearing daffodils or leeks, and traditional Welsh music and food.

03-02.title: Ethiopia's Victory at Adwa Day
03-02.description: March 2 commemorates Ethiopia's 1896 victory over Italy at the Battle of Adwa, celebrated as a symbol of African resistance to colonialism.

03-02.title: Myanmar's Peasants' Day
03-02.description: March 2 is Peasants' Day in Myanmar, honoring farmers with agricultural shows, traditional performances, and exhibitions of farming techniques.

03-03.title: Bulgaria's Liberation Day
03-03.description: March 3 celebrates Bulgaria's 1878 liberation from Ottoman rule, marked by ceremonies at the Shipka Pass and nationwide flag displays.

03-03.title: Japan's Hinamatsuri (Doll Festival)
03-03.description: March 3 is Hinamatsuri in Japan, celebrating girls with elaborate displays of traditional dolls, peach blossoms, and special diamond-shaped rice cakes.

03-04.title: Ghana's Independence Day Eve
03-04.description: March 4 features Independence Eve celebrations in Ghana, with traditional drumming, dancing, and preparations for the main Independence Day on March 6.

03-04.title: Scotland's Traditional Working Day
03-04.description: In parts of Scotland, March 4 was historically when farm workers would change employers, marked by hiring fairs called 'feeing markets.'

03-05.title: Australia's Labour Day in Western Australia
03-05.description: First Monday in March is Labour Day in Western Australia, celebrated with community festivals, sports events, and family activities.

03-05.title: Kuwait's Camel Racing Season Finals
03-05.description: Early March marks the finals of Kuwait's camel racing season, featuring robot jockeys and traditional celebrations in the desert racetracks.

03-06.title: Ghana's Independence Day
03-06.description: March 6 celebrates Ghana's 1957 independence from Britain, marked by parades at Independence Square and cultural festivals across the country.

03-06.title: Algeria's Anniversary of the 1962 Ceasefire
03-06.description: March 6 commemorates the 1962 ceasefire ending the Algerian War, remembered with ceremonies honoring independence fighters.

03-07.title: Liberia's Decoration Day
03-07.description: Second Wednesday in March is Decoration Day in Liberia, when families clean and decorate graves of ancestors with flowers and offerings.

03-07.title: Mongolia's Military Day
03-07.description: March 7 is Military Day in Mongolia, celebrating the armed forces with parades, demonstrations, and ceremonies honoring military personnel.

03-08.title: International Women's Day (Global)
03-08.description: March 8 is celebrated worldwide, with Russia giving flowers to all women, Italy giving mimosa blossoms, and China giving women a half-day off work.

03-08.title: Syria's Revolution Day
03-08.description: March 8 commemorates the 1963 coup that brought the Ba'ath Party to power in Syria, marked by official ceremonies and speeches.

03-09.title: Barbados' National Heroes Day
03-09.description: April 28 is National Heroes Day in Barbados, but celebrations and educational programs about national heroes begin throughout March.

03-09.title: Taiwan's Tomb Sweeping Festival Preparations
03-09.description: Early March begins preparations for Taiwan's Tomb Sweeping Festival, with families cleaning ancestral graves and preparing traditional foods.

03-10.title: Tibet's Uprising Day
03-10.description: March 10 commemorates the 1959 Tibetan uprising, observed by Tibetan exiles worldwide with prayer ceremonies and cultural events.

03-10.title: Mali's Martyrs' Day
03-10.description: March 10 is Martyrs' Day in Mali, honoring those who died in the 1991 protests that led to democratic reforms, marked by remembrance ceremonies.

03-11.title: Lithuania's Restoration of Independence Day
03-11.description: March 11 celebrates Lithuania's 1990 declaration restoring independence from the Soviet Union, marked by concerts and flag ceremonies.

03-11.title: Vanuatu's Chief's Day
03-11.description: March 11 is Chief's Day in Vanuatu, honoring traditional chiefs with ceremonies featuring kava drinking, pig exchanges, and custom dancing.

03-12.title: Mauritius' Independence Day
03-12.description: March 12 celebrates Mauritius' 1968 independence from Britain, marked by flag-raising ceremonies, cultural shows, and the Mauritian Sega dance.

03-12.title: Gabon's Renovation Day
03-12.description: March 12 is Renovation Day in Gabon, commemorating the founding of the Gabonese Democratic Party in 1968, marked by political rallies.

03-13.title: Grenada's Thanksgiving Day
03-13.description: March 13 is Thanksgiving Day in Grenada, giving thanks for the 1979 revolution, marked by church services and community gatherings.

03-13.title: Myanmar's Full Moon of Tabaung Festival
03-13.description: March's full moon marks Myanmar's Tabaung Festival, featuring pagoda festivals, traditional puppet shows, and sand stupa building competitions.

03-14.title: π Day (Global Mathematics Celebration)
03-14.description: March 14 (3/14) celebrates the mathematical constant π, with math enthusiasts worldwide holding competitions, eating pie, and discussing mathematics.

03-14.title: Andorra's Constitution Day
03-14.description: March 14 is Constitution Day in Andorra, commemorating the 1993 constitution that established the principality as a parliamentary democracy.

03-15.title: Hungary's National Day
03-15.description: March 15 commemorates the 1848 Hungarian Revolution, marked by wearing national cockades and ceremonies at the National Museum in Budapest.

03-15.title: Liberia's J.J. Roberts' Birthday
03-15.description: March 15 celebrates the birthday of Liberia's first president, Joseph Jenkins Roberts, with ceremonies at his monument and educational events.

03-16.title: Black Press Day (Global Journalism)
03-16.description: March 16 celebrates the founding of the first Black American newspaper in 1827, observed by media organizations worldwide highlighting diverse voices.

03-16.title: Mexico's Birth of Benito Juárez
03-16.description: March 21 celebrates Benito Juárez, but educational programs about Mexico's first indigenous president begin around March 16 in schools.

03-17.title: Ireland's St. Patrick's Day (Global Celebration)
03-17.description: Celebrated worldwide with green attire, parades, and Irish culture - from dyeing Chicago River green to massive parades in New York and Dublin.

03-17.title: Bangladesh's Sheikh Mujibur Rahman's Birthday
03-17.description: March 17 commemorates the birthday of Bangladesh's founding father, marked by wreath-laying ceremonies and cultural programs nationwide.

03-18.title: Aruba's Flag Day and National Anthem Day
03-18.description: March 18 celebrates Aruba's flag and national anthem, marked by ceremonies, cultural shows, and the Miss Aruba pageant finale.

03-18.title: Mongolia's Soldiers' Day
03-18.description: March 18 is Soldiers' Day in Mongolia, honoring military personnel with ceremonies, awards, and traditional wrestling competitions.

03-19.title: Switzerland's Basel Fasnacht (Carnival)
03-19.description: March 19 often marks Basel's Fasnacht, beginning at 4 AM with the Morgestraich parade of illuminated lanterns through the old town.

03-19.title: St. Joseph's Day (Multiple Countries)
03-19.description: Celebrated in Italy with St. Joseph's altars, in Spain with Fallas festival bonfires, and in Poland with drowning Marzanna winter effigies.

03-20.title: Tunisia's Independence Day
03-20.description: March 20 celebrates Tunisia's 1956 independence from France, marked by parades, cultural events, and the president's address to the nation.

03-20.title: International Day of Happiness (UN)
03-20.description: March 20 promotes happiness as a human right, celebrated globally with events focusing on well-being, meditation, and community activities.

03-21.title: Namibia's Independence Day
03-21.description: March 21 celebrates Namibia's 1990 independence from South Africa, marked by ceremonies at Independence Stadium and cultural festivals.

03-21.title: Iran's Nowruz (Persian New Year)
03-21.description: March 21 marks Nowruz, celebrated across Iran, Afghanistan, Central Asia, and diaspora communities with haft-sin tables and jumping over fires.

03-22.title: World Water Day (UN)
03-22.description: March 22 raises awareness about water conservation, celebrated globally with educational programs, clean-up campaigns, and policy discussions.

03-22.title: Puerto Rico's Emancipation Day
03-22.description: March 22 commemorates the 1873 abolition of slavery in Puerto Rico, marked by cultural events and discussions about Afro-Puerto Rican heritage.

03-23.title: Pakistan's Republic Day
03-23.description: March 23 commemorates the 1940 Lahore Resolution calling for a separate Muslim state, marked by parades and patriotic ceremonies nationwide.

03-23.title: Bolivia's Day of the Sea
03-23.description: March 23 commemorates Bolivia's loss of coastline to Chile in 1879, marked by ceremonies demanding sea access and patriotic events.

03-24.title: Argentina's National Day of Memory for Truth and Justice
03-24.description: March 24 commemorates victims of the 1976 military dictatorship, marked by marches, memorials, and human rights discussions.

03-24.title: Thailand's Chakri Memorial Day
03-24.description: April 6 is Chakri Day, but March 24 begins royal ceremonies honoring Thailand's current dynasty with temple visits and traditional rituals.

03-25.title: Greece's Independence Day
03-25.description: March 25 celebrates Greece's 1821 declaration of independence from the Ottoman Empire, marked by parades, flag displays, and traditional dancing.

03-25.title: Slovakia's Struggle for Human Rights Day
03-25.description: March 25 commemorates the 1988 Candle Demonstration for human rights, marking the beginning of the Velvet Revolution in Czechoslovakia.

03-26.title: Bangladesh's Independence Day
03-26.description: March 26 celebrates Bangladesh's 1971 declaration of independence, marked by parades, cultural programs, and tributes at the National Memorial.

03-26.title: Cuba's Birthday of José Antonio Echeverría
03-26.description: March 26 commemorates the birthday of student revolutionary José Antonio Echeverría, honored with ceremonies at the University of Havana.

03-27.title: World Theatre Day (Global)
03-27.description: March 27 celebrates theatre worldwide, with special performances, backstage tours, and the circulation of an annual message from a prominent theatre figure.

03-27.title: Myanmar's Armed Forces Day
03-27.description: March 27 is Armed Forces Day in Myanmar, featuring military parades, displays of traditional strength, and ceremonies honoring soldiers.

03-28.title: Czech Republic's Teachers' Day
03-28.description: March 28 commemorates the birth of Jan Amos Comenius, the 'teacher of nations,' marked by awards for outstanding educators and educational events.

03-28.title: Serbia's Earth Hour Observance
03-28.description: Last Saturday of March features Earth Hour, observed in Serbia by turning off lights at landmarks like Belgrade Fortress for environmental awareness.

03-29.title: Madagascar's Martyrs' Day
03-29.description: March 29 commemorates the 1947 Malagasy Uprising against French colonial rule, marked by ceremonies honoring independence fighters.

03-29.title: Taiwan's Youth Day
03-29.description: March 29 is Youth Day in Taiwan, commemorating the 1911 Huanghuagang Uprising, marked by ceremonies honoring revolutionary youth.

03-30.title: Palestine's Land Day
03-30.description: March 30 commemorates the 1976 protests against Israeli land confiscation, marked by demonstrations and events affirming Palestinian land rights.

03-30.title: Spain's Balearic Islands Day
03-30.description: March 31 is Balearic Islands Day, but celebrations begin on March 30 with traditional dances, music, and cultural exhibitions.

03-31.title: Malta's Freedom Day
03-31.description: March 31 celebrates the 1979 withdrawal of British troops from Malta, marked by ceremonies at the War Memorial and traditional regattas.

03-31.title: US Virgin Islands' Transfer Day
03-31.description: March 31 commemorates the 1917 transfer from Denmark to the United States, marked by cultural festivals showcasing African, European, and Caribbean heritage.
